news_summary: Nearly 800 young Austrians are benefiting from free travel across Europe, while the EU plans to ease costs for farmers by temporarily suspending fertilizer import duties.
news_summary_fr: Près de 800 jeunes Autrichiens bénéficient de la gratuité des transports à travers l'Europe, tandis que l'UE prévoit d'alléger les coûts pour les agriculteurs en suspendant temporairement les droits d'importation sur les engrais.
news_summary_es: Cerca de 800 jóvenes austriacos se benefician de viajes gratuitos por Europa, mientras que la UE planea aliviar los costes para los agricultores mediante la suspensión temporal de los aranceles sobre las importaciones de fertilizantes.

articles.title: DiscoverEU: Almost 800 young Austrians travel for free across Europe
articles.summary: The European Commission announced the winners of the autumn round of its DiscoverEU program in Brussels on Wednesday. Among them were 798 Austrians under the age of 18.
articles.content:
Brussels (APA) – More than 40,000 young Europeans under 18 can once again travel across Europe this year with free train tickets. The European Commission announced the winners of the autumn round of its DiscoverEU program in Brussels on Wednesday. This also allows 798 Austrians to explore the cultures of all European countries by train and with a youth card for up to 30 days within one year.

All people who were born between 1 January and 31 December 2007 and come from EU member states or Erasmus+-associated countries (Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, North Macedonia, Serbia and Turkey) were eligible to participate. According to the EU Commission, a total of 246,782 applications were submitted. Since 2018, almost two million young people have applied for 431,931 travel passes. As in previous years, special regulations will make it possible for travelers from islands or remote areas to enter. Participants with a disability or health problems may be accompanied.

Youth card with 23,000 discounts

In addition to the travel pass, participants will once again receive the DiscoverEU youth card with over 23,000 discounts for public transport, hotels, food, as well as cultural, sports and other activities in more than 30 European countries. In addition, the national Erasmus+ agencies organize meetings before, during and after the trip. In Austria, OeAD – Agency for Education and Internationalisation is responsible.

DiscoverEU is a central component of the Erasmus+ exchange program and is intended to promote the mobility of young people, environmentally friendly travel, cultural exchange and European unity. The next application round will start in spring 2026. It is open to applicants born between 1 July 2007 and 30 June 2008. “This special edition for the 40th anniversary of the Schengen area reminds us that mobility is a right that we value; a cornerstone of our shared European identity,” said EU Youth Commissioner Glenn Micallef. (8.1.2026)
articles.reasoning: The article describes a large-scale initiative by the European Commission that enables nearly 800 young Austrians, among tens of thousands of young Europeans, to travel freely across Europe by train. This program promotes cultural exchange, European unity, environmentally friendly travel, and youth mobility, which have broad societal benefits. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights a positive policy impacting many young people across multiple countries.
articles.personality_title: Nearly 800 young Austrians win free train trips across Europe through DiscoverEU
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Commission runs a program called DiscoverEU that gives free train tickets to young people under 18 from EU countries and some nearby nations. It aims to encourage travel, cultural exchange, and environmentally friendly ways to explore Europe.

**What happened** – In the latest round announced in Brussels, 798 young Austrians born in 2007 won free train passes. They can travel for up to 30 days within a year across Europe. This is part of a group of over 40,000 young Europeans selected from nearly 247,000 applicants.

**Impact** – This program helps young people discover other cultures and meet new people while traveling by train, which is better for the environment than flying. It also gives them a youth card with discounts for things like hotels, food, and activities in over 30 countries, making travel more affordable and rich in experience.

**What's next step** – The next chance to apply will open in spring 2026 for those born between July 2007 and June 2008. Meanwhile, participants get support from local agencies before, during, and after their trips to help make the most of their journeys.

**One-sentence takeaway** – DiscoverEU is opening doors for hundreds of young Austrians to explore Europe sustainably and affordably, connecting cultures and encouraging travel by train.
articles.personality_title_fr: Près de 800 jeunes Autrichiens gagnent des voyages gratuits en train à travers l’Europe grâce à DiscoverEU
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La Commission européenne organise un programme appelé DiscoverEU qui offre des billets de train gratuits aux jeunes de moins de 18 ans des pays de l’UE et de certains pays voisins. Il vise à encourager les voyages, les échanges culturels et les déplacements écologiques en Europe.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Lors de la dernière sélection annoncée à Bruxelles, 798 jeunes Autrichiens nés en 2007 ont gagné des passes de train gratuits. Ils peuvent voyager jusqu’à 30 jours en un an à travers l’Europe. Cela fait partie d’un groupe de plus de 40 000 jeunes européens choisis parmi près de 247 000 candidats.

**Impact** – Ce programme permet aux jeunes de découvrir d’autres cultures et de rencontrer de nouvelles personnes tout en voyageant en train, un moyen plus écologique que l’avion. Ils reçoivent aussi une carte jeune offrant des réductions sur les hôtels, la nourriture et les activités dans plus de 30 pays, rendant le voyage plus abordable et riche en expériences.

**La prochaine étape** – La prochaine période de candidature ouvrira au printemps 2026 pour les jeunes nés entre juillet 2007 et juin 2008. En attendant, les participants bénéficient d’un soutien des agences locales avant, pendant et après leurs voyages pour profiter au maximum de leur expérience.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – DiscoverEU permet à des centaines de jeunes Autrichiens d’explorer l’Europe de manière durable et économique, en reliant les cultures et en favorisant le voyage en train.
articles.personality_title_es: Casi 800 jóvenes austriacos ganan viajes gratuitos en tren por Europa gracias a DiscoverEU
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Comisión Europea tiene un programa llamado DiscoverEU que ofrece boletos de tren gratuitos a jóvenes menores de 18 años de países de la UE y algunos países cercanos. El objetivo es fomentar los viajes, el intercambio cultural y el transporte ecológico en Europa.

**Qué pasó** – En la última ronda anunciada en Bruselas, 798 jóvenes austriacos nacidos en 2007 ganaron pases gratuitos para viajar en tren. Pueden viajar hasta 30 días dentro de un año por Europa. Esto forma parte de un grupo de más de 40,000 jóvenes europeos seleccionados entre casi 247,000 solicitudes.

**Impacto** – Este programa ayuda a los jóvenes a descubrir otras culturas y conocer gente nueva mientras viajan en tren, lo que es mejor para el medio ambiente que volar. También reciben una tarjeta juvenil con descuentos para hoteles, comida y actividades en más de 30 países, haciendo que viajar sea más barato y enriquecedor.

**Próximo paso** – La próxima convocatoria abrirá en primavera de 2026 para quienes nacieron entre julio de 2007 y junio de 2008. Mientras tanto, los participantes reciben apoyo de agencias locales antes, durante y después de sus viajes para aprovechar al máximo la experiencia.

**Frase clave** – DiscoverEU está abriendo oportunidades para que cientos de jóvenes austriacos exploren Europa de forma sostenible y económica, conectando culturas y promoviendo el viaje en tren.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a vintage European train winding through a colorful mosaic of iconic landmarks from various European countries, with youthful silhouettes carrying travel cards, set against a soft, natural palette that evokes cultural connection, exploration, and unity across the continent.

articles.title: EU wants to temporarily suspend import duties on fertilizers to help farmers
articles.summary: The European Commission launched a number of proposals on Wednesday to address the concerns of farmers. Among other things, it wants to temporarily scrap import duties on fertilizers and also ban three pesticides that are prohibited in the EU in imported products.
articles.content:
The European Commission launched a number of proposals on Wednesday to address the concerns of farmers. Among other things, it wants to temporarily scrap import duties on fertilizers and also ban three pesticides that are prohibited in the EU in imported products.

The Commission and the Cypriot presidency of the EU Council organized an informal meeting of Agriculture Ministers on Wednesday following the intense farmers’ protests on 18 December on the sidelines of the European summit. To respond to the farmers’ concerns, the Commission wants, among other things, to temporarily and retroactively suspend import tariffs on fertilizers such as ammonia and urea in order to reduce the prices of artificial fertilizers, and also to adjust the border tax mechanism (CBAM) to allow temporary exemptions for fertilizers.

“While prices have stabilized, fertilizer prices remain 60 percent higher than in 2020. That is simply not sustainable,” said European Commissioner for Trade Maros Sefcovic at a press conference after the meeting.

The Commission also wants to ban three pesticides that are prohibited within the EU in imported products as well, and is working on a series of more technical adjustments and simplifications to the existing regulations. On Tuesday/yesterday, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen had already proposed to release 45 billion euros early for farmers in the next multiannual budget.

Flemish Minister of Agriculture Jo Brouns, who represented Belgium together with his Walloon colleague Anne-Catherine Dalcq, nevertheless calls the measures “far from sufficient” to tackle the structural problems and the fundamental bottlenecks. “As long as farmers in Europe continue to face an accumulation of obligations, inspections and sanctions, while competitors from outside the EU gain access to the market under less stringent conditions, the playing field remains uneven,” he says.

The meeting took place ahead of a possible vote by the member states on Friday on the EU-Mercosur free trade agreement. The European Commission wants to officially sign that agreement as soon as possible, but does not yet have the necessary support from the member states. Mercosur was not officially on the ministers’ agenda on Wednesday, but the Commission’s concessions are seen as a way to get the countries that are still hesitating over the line.

Attention is focused in particular on Italy, which until recently opposed the agreement but, according to various media, could change its position. Without Italy, it will be very difficult for the opponents of the agreement – led by France and Poland – to find a blocking minority. Belgium has announced that it will have to abstain.

On Thursday and Friday, farmers’ protests against Mercosur will again take place in Belgium and France.

(Brussels, 7 January 2026)
articles.reasoning: The European Commission's proposal to temporarily suspend import duties on fertilizers aims to reduce costs for farmers across the EU, addressing a significant economic challenge with broad societal impact. Additionally, banning prohibited pesticides in imports promotes environmental and health standards. These policy actions have meaningful positive effects on agriculture sustainability and food security for a large population, though some stakeholders consider the measures insufficient.
articles.personality_title: EU proposes temporary cut on fertilizer taxes to ease costs for farmers
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Farmers across the European Union have been facing high fertilizer prices and worries about unfair competition from imports. Recent protests by farmers highlighted these concerns and pushed EU leaders to find solutions.

**What happened** – On January 7, 2026, the European Commission proposed temporarily removing import taxes on fertilizers like ammonia and urea. This aims to lower fertilizer prices for farmers. The Commission also wants to ban three pesticides that are already forbidden inside the EU from imported products. These steps came after a meeting of Agriculture Ministers organized by the Commission and the Cypriot EU Council presidency.

**Impact** – Fertilizer prices are still about 60% higher than in 2020, making farming more expensive. Temporarily cutting import taxes can help farmers afford fertilizers, which are essential for growing crops. Banning harmful pesticides in imports protects the environment and health by keeping EU standards consistent. These actions show the EU is responding to farmers’ challenges and working to keep food production stable.

**What's next step** – EU member countries are expected to vote soon on a trade deal with Mercosur, a group of South American countries. The Commission hopes these proposals will encourage more countries to support the deal. Meanwhile, farmers in Belgium and France plan more protests, showing the issue is still important to them.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU’s plan to temporarily suspend fertilizer taxes and ban certain pesticides in imports aims to lower costs for farmers while protecting environmental standards.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’UE propose une suspension temporaire des taxes sur les engrais pour aider les agriculteurs
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les agriculteurs de l’Union européenne font face à des prix élevés des engrais et craignent une concurrence déloyale des importations. Des manifestations récentes ont poussé les dirigeants de l’UE à trouver des solutions.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 7 janvier 2026, la Commission européenne a proposé de supprimer temporairement les taxes à l’importation sur des engrais comme l’ammoniac et l’urée. Cela vise à faire baisser les prix des engrais pour les agriculteurs. La Commission veut aussi interdire trois pesticides déjà interdits dans l’UE dans les produits importés. Ces mesures ont été annoncées après une réunion des ministres de l’Agriculture organisée par la Commission et la présidence chypriote du Conseil de l’UE.

**Impact** – Les prix des engrais restent environ 60 % plus élevés qu’en 2020, ce qui rend l’agriculture plus coûteuse. La suppression temporaire des taxes peut aider les agriculteurs à acheter les engrais nécessaires à leurs cultures. L’interdiction des pesticides dangereux dans les importations protège l’environnement et la santé en maintenant les normes de l’UE. Ces actions montrent que l’UE répond aux difficultés des agriculteurs et travaille à la stabilité de la production alimentaire.

**Prochaine étape** – Les pays membres de l’UE doivent bientôt voter sur un accord commercial avec le Mercosur, un groupe de pays sud-américains. La Commission espère que ces propositions encourageront plus de pays à soutenir l’accord. Pendant ce temps, les agriculteurs en Belgique et en France prévoient d’autres manifestations, ce qui montre que la question reste importante pour eux.

**En une phrase** – Le plan de l’UE de suspendre temporairement les taxes sur les engrais et d’interdire certains pesticides dans les importations vise à réduire les coûts pour les agriculteurs tout en protégeant les normes environnementales.
articles.personality_title_es: La UE propone suspender temporalmente los impuestos a los fertilizantes para aliviar costos a agricultores
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los agricultores de la Unión Europea enfrentan altos precios de fertilizantes y preocupaciones sobre competencia desleal de importaciones. Las recientes protestas de agricultores impulsaron a los líderes de la UE a buscar soluciones.

**Qué pasó** – El 7 de enero de 2026, la Comisión Europea propuso eliminar temporalmente los impuestos a la importación de fertilizantes como amoníaco y urea. Esto busca bajar los precios para los agricultores. También quiere prohibir tres pesticidas ya prohibidos dentro de la UE en productos importados. Estas medidas se anunciaron tras una reunión de ministros de Agricultura organizada por la Comisión y la presidencia chipriota del Consejo de la UE.

**Impacto** – Los precios de fertilizantes siguen siendo un 60 % más altos que en 2020, lo que hace que la agricultura sea más cara. La suspensión temporal de impuestos puede ayudar a los agricultores a comprar los fertilizantes necesarios para sus cultivos. Prohibir pesticidas dañinos en las importaciones protege el medio ambiente y la salud al mantener los estándares de la UE. Estas acciones muestran que la UE responde a los desafíos de los agricultores y trabaja para mantener la producción de alimentos estable.

**Próximo paso** – Los países miembros de la UE votarán pronto sobre un acuerdo comercial con Mercosur, un grupo de países sudamericanos. La Comisión espera que estas propuestas animen a más países a apoyar el acuerdo. Mientras tanto, agricultores en Bélgica y Francia planean más protestas, lo que muestra que el tema sigue siendo importante para ellos.

**En una frase** – El plan de la UE de suspender temporalmente los impuestos a fertilizantes y prohibir ciertos pesticidas en las importaciones busca reducir costos para los agricultores y proteger los estándares ambientales.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed painting of a fertile European farmland bathed in warm, natural light, showing golden fields with symbolic bags labeled with stylized ammonia and urea molecules gently resting near the soil, while a balanced scale made of intertwining wheat stalks holds a cluster of three crossed-out pesticide droplets on one side, all set against a calm horizon that blends soft earth tones and muted greens.
